description: From New Latin palaeotypus (“which dates from the early days of printing; incunabulum, paleotype”), synchronically palaeo- +‎ type.

entries.meaning: An old book printed between 1500 and 1550.
examples: The library of the British Museum is  […]  rich in manuscripts, rich in palaeotypes, rich in the science, history, and literature of every age and nation.

entries.meaning: (historical) A phonetic alphabet developed by Alexander John Ellis to represent all spoken sounds of English by means of the printing types that were in common use in the mid-19th century, one of the predecessors of IPA.
examples: Of course for publication in a newspaper, my palaeotype would not answer, but my glossotype would enable the author to give his Pennsylvania German in an English form and much more intelligibly.
